content:
JAPAN

Hitachi (6501 JT) - Showa Denko (4004 JT) to launch bid for Co. unit Hitachi Chemical (7181 JT) valued at JPY 964bln and Hitachi will also sell its diagnostic imaging business for JPY 179bln to FujiFilm (4901 JT). In other news, Hitachi is to settle South Africa power plant project dispute with Mitsubishi Heavy (7011 JT) for JPY 130bln, while it lowered FY19/20 net forecast to JPY 170bln from JPY 360bln following the settlement. (Newswires)

Isuzu (7202 JT) - Co. agrees to buy Volvo’s UD Trucks unit as part of a strategic alliance for commercial vehicles valued at JPY 250bln. (Newswires)

Japan Post Insurance (7181 JT) - Co. noted that improper sales reached 12.8k cases and that 670 cases violated laws or internal regulations. (Newswires)

Japan Tobacco (2914 JT) - Co. November domestic cigarette sales volumes fell 4.8% Y/Y to 5.8bln units and domestic cigarette revenue fell 4.7% Y/Y to JPY 37.3bln. (Newswires)

Nitori (9843 JT) - Co. may report 9-month oper. profit rose 8% Y/Y to JPY 84bln. (Nikkei)

NTT Data (9613 JT) - NTT Data Services will acquire NETE. (Newswires)

Rakuten (4755 JT) - Japan FTC conveyed possible antitrust concerns regarding Co. free shipping plan. (Newswires)

SoftBank (9984 JT) - Co. Vison Fund employees are thought to depict a culture of recklessness, according to press reports. (Newswires)

Tv Tokyo Holdings (9413 JT) - Co. is planning to set up a new animation company in China. (Nikkei)

Other News - Japan government raised FY20/21 real GDP growth forecast to 1.4% from 1.2%. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Kia Motors (000270 KS) - Co. workers began a partial strike yesterday for an increase in wages. (Yonhap)

LG Electronics (066570 KS) - Co. has conducted a voluntary recall of clothes dryers in South Korea. (Yonhap) SK Corp (003600 KS) - Co. and South Korea National Pension formed a KRW1.0tln Vietnam fund. (Newswires)

Geopolitics - Bipartisan group of US senators warned of further economic sanctions on North Korea in response to any provocation such as a long-range missile test. (Yonhap) 

Other News - South Korea Finance Ministry said the domestic markets are showing stable trend as sentiment improves. (Newswires)

content:
ASIA-PAC

White House Trade Advisor Navarro suggested that China will be purchasing USD 200bln of agricultural purchases over 4 different categories across a 2-year horizon. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK Government’s plan is to get the Brexit Withdrawal Agreement Bill through House of Commons stages on the 7th, 8th and 9th of January, according to Spectator's Forsyth. (Twitter)

European Parliament has reportedly pencilled in 29th January 2020 as the day to vote on the Brexit withdrawal deal, contingent on Westminster plan, according to Guardian's Rankin. (Twitter)

  • UK CPI YY (Nov) 1.5% vs. Exp. 1.4% (Prev. 1.5%). (Newswires)
  • EU HICP Final YY (Nov) 1.0% vs. Exp. 1.0% (Prev. 1.0%)

 

FX

Canadian CPI Inflation YY (Nov) 2.2% vs. Exp. 2.2% (Prev. 1.9%). (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e -1.085M vs. Exp. -1.288M (Prev. 0.822M). (Newswires)

 

US

Fed’s Williams (Voter, Neutral) said he expects to see growth around 2.25%, unemployment around 3.5% and inflation remaining soft as he hasn’t seen inflationary pressures emerge. Williams also reiterated data dependence and stated monetary policy is accommodative and is supporting growth, while he added that monetary policy is in the right place and a material change in economic outlook will cause him to change outlook. (Newswires)

Fed's Evans (2020 Non-Voter, Dove) said the US labour market is vibrant and the economy is doing "remarkably well", while he suggested that monetary policy is at a good setting currently and its a good time to watch the data. Furthermore, Evans added it would take a lot of new data to change his opinion and inflation would need to go meaningfully above 2% for him to support monetary tightening. (Newswires)

Fed's Barkin (Non-Voter, Hawkish) believes we are in a reasonable place on the balance sheet and that policy is still accommodative, while he added that he is very focused on data and that it is hard to find evidence of deteriorating credit quality at the moment, but the Fed is watching the data. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Tesla (TSLA) printed all-time highs rising 4% after reports it is to cut the price of its Model 3 Sedan in China by 20% or more. Dish (DISH) traded higher today after its co-founder and Chairman Ergen announced he has three letters from three banks prepared to offer USD 10bln to fund its new wireless network. Macerich (MAC) benefitted from an upgrade to neutral from underweight at JP Morgan. Macy’s (M) higher after a note from Cleveland research turning positive on the company after being a bear for 1.5 years, citing Q4 to date tracking has improved from Q3, adding comps appear inline and promotions less aggressive. Nvidia (NVDA) partnered with Tencent (700 HK) to launch a cloud gaming service in China. FedEx (FDX) traded lower after top and bottom line misses whilst also cutting its FY20 EPS view, noting the decline was due to weak global economic conditions, higher ground costs, loss of business from a large customer. The delivery company also noted the late timing of Thanksgiving saw a shift of Cyberweek into December which negatively impacted results. Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) and Peugeot (UG FP) agreed to a 50/50 merger which would value the combined company at USD 50bln, making it the 4th largest automaker in terms of volume, and 3rd largest in terms of revenue. However, all is not clear yet as the two still face regulatory hurdles from both the US and EU. Broadcom (AVGO) Is reportedly looking to sell its RF wireless chip unit, which is reportedly valued at USD 10bln. 9to5 Mac reported an opinion piece that Apple (AAPL) could be a potential suitor as it is already researching its own RF technology, making the tech behemoth a likely suitor. SPX +0.03% at 3192, NDX +0.05% at 8820, DJI -0.09% at 28,241.

The T-Note, alongside the Bund, moved lower on Wednesday as participants sold duration, with risk appetite remaining elevated in the final few weeks of the year. Some have noted that while activity is winding down for the year, one desk noted a couple of themes still in play: there is still interest in curve steepeners, as seen over the last week or so, particularly with accounts adding to 2s10s; another theme that is clear is the selling of volatility, both in Europe and the US, with the desk noting that the selling came despite the recent fall in implied volatility in both Treasuries and Bunds. "One area where flows have remained fairly strong is the option market," the strategist said, "perhaps some think the drop off in vol has gone too far," and notes that "the moves over last Christmas perhaps prompted some to position for a repeat, when vol spiked in both fixed income and equities". T-note (H0) futures settled 9 ticks lower at 128-05+.

ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASE CALENDAR IS AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION OF THE WEBSITE: Highlights include New Zealand GDP and Trade Data, Australian Employment Change and Unemployment Rate, BoJ Policy Decision
Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 18th December 2019: Subdued trade as participants head into holiday season
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities flat, Treasuries down, Dollar up, Crude flat.
  • REAR VIEW: Dismal FDX earnings, FCA IM & UG FP agree to 50/50 merger; Bullish EIA report, Canadian CPI in line, solid German IFO data
  • COMING UP: Data: NZ GDP & Trade; AU jobs, UK Retail sales, US Existing Home Sales. Events: Rate decisions from BoJ, BoE, Riksbank, Norgesbank and Banxico; Trump impeachment vote (Tonight). Speakers: ECB’s Lane.

* FED: Fed’s Williams (voter) said monetary policy is in the right place, is accommodative and growth supportive, whilst reiterating data dependence. Williams expects to see growth around 2.25%, unemployment around 3.5% and inflation remaining soft, stating that he hasn’t seen inflationary pressures emerge. The NY Fed President very much reiterated the wider FOMC communications but did describe risks to the downside as still significant (some have announced them as less pronounced now), citing trade and geopolitical uncertainty. Williams said overnight repo operations have been very effective and money markets are moving smoothly. Fed's Evans (non-voter) said monetary policy is at a good setting currently and he is data dependent, where it would require a lot of new data to change his opinion, echoing other policymakers in that inflation would have to go meaningfully above 2% for him to support monetary tightening. Evans expressed his concern with low inflation but said the economy is strong, although he does see employment growth moderating lower to closer to 100,00 jobs a month.

* CANADIAN INFLATION (NOV): CPI Y/Y rose to a six-month high at 2.2% from 1.9%, as expected, with the M/M falling as expected 0.1%. Meanwhile, the BoC's core CPI measures averaged a cycle-high 2.2%. RBC’s analysts suggest the rise in the headline was mainly a result of base effects following the energy price slump in the tail-end of 2018, which it believes should hold inflation above 2% for the Y/Y figure until it washes out around March 2020, although caveats that there is evidence of firming in underlying inflation trends, as seen in the BoC’s average core measures. “We don't think today's inflation data ties the Bank of Canada's hands,” the bank says, adding, “Policymakers will likely be more influenced by next week's October GDP report, which we think will set up for another quarter of sub-trend growth in Q4. That should leave the door open to a rate cut next year, even with underlying inflation now on the high side of 2%.”

* GERMANY IFO (DEC): The headline business expectations (seen as a proxy for German growth momentum) rose to 96.3 (exp. 95.5, prev. rev. 95.1), which some desks have taken as another sign of downside risks abating within the German economy. Expectations improved to the best reading since June at 93.8 from 92.3. Sentiment was better in the manufacturing and services industries. The hard data for Q4 has not been painting as optimistic a picture as the Ifo has in recent months, with the former having now seen three consecutive months of improvement in the forward-looking expectations metric. Pantheon Macroeconomics said this is usually a bullish sign of a turning point, but the key question is then how strong the upturn will be, "At the moment, survey and hard data suggest that the German economy stalled in the second half of 2019, and we expect only a slow pick-up in H1 2020, but a rebound nonetheless." The Ifo itself says the data is consistent with German growth of +0.2% in Q4, adding that the German economy was heading into the new year with confidence; though the industrial sector is still in recession, noting it will take a while to get out of it.

* BOE PREVIEW: Bank of England Monetary Policy Decision and Minutes due Thursday 19th December at 12:00GMT / 07:00EST. MPC expected to vote 7-2 in favour of standing pat on rates at 0.75%. Post-election uncertainty reprieve could be short-lived as focus shifts to the transition period. Policymakers could be forced to lower rates in 2020 in the absence of an improvement in economic data. Click here for full preview.

BOJ PREVIEW: BoJ Monetary Policy Decision due Thursday 19th December after 02:30GMT / 20:30CST / 10:30HKT. BoJ expected to keep all monetary policy settings unchanged as it has done for the entire of 2019. The latest Japanese data releases have been mixed and would therefore favour a wait and see approach. Governor Kuroda has reiterated the BoJ won't hesitate to ease further if momentum towards the inflation target comes under threat. Click here for the full preview.

* T-NOTE (H0) FUTURES SETTLED 9 TICKS LOWER AT 128-05+. The T-Note, alongside the Bund, moved lower on Wednesday as participants sold duration, with risk appetite remaining elevated in the final few weeks of the year. Some have noted that while activity is winding down for the year, one desk noted a couple of themes still in play: there is still interest in curve steepeners, as seen over the last week or so, particularly with accounts adding to 2s10s; another theme that is clear is the selling of volatility, both in Europe and the US, with the desk noting that the selling came despite the recent fall in implied volatility in both Treasuries and Bunds. "One area where flows have remained fairly strong is the option market," the strategist said, "perhaps some think the drop off in vol has gone too far," and notes that "the moves over last Christmas perhaps prompted some to position for a repeat, when vol spiked in both fixed income and equities."

* WTI (G0) SETTLES 0.02 LOWER AT USD 60.85/BBL; BRENT (G0) SETTLES USD 0.07 HIGHER AT USD 66.17/BBL. Oil prices settled little changed after reversing their losses on the back of the bullish EIA inventory report. The benchmarks had been on the back-foot since the surprise 4.7mln bbl build in crude stocks reported by the API on Tuesday evening. However, the EIA failed to confirm the build and instead reported a 1.1mln bbl draw (vs. exp. -1.3mln), the builds in the products were also less acute than the API report. Elsewhere in the EIA report, Cushing stocks drew by 0.27mln bbls, refinery utilisation remained unchanged, as did production at 12.8mln BPD, whilst net imports fell by 541k BPD to 2.946mln BPD, with both imports falling and exports rising.

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +0.03% at 3192, NDX +0.05% at 8820, DJI -0.09% at 28,241.

* EARNINGS: FedEx (FDX) traded lower after top and bottom line misses whilst also cutting its FY20 EPS view, noting the decline was due to weak global economic conditions, higher ground costs, loss of business from a large customer. The delivery company also noted the late timing of Thanksgiving saw a shift of Cyberweek into December which negatively impacted results. The results also weighed on competitor UPS (UPS), where analysts at Morgan Stanley highlighted the earnings hold a negative read for the company. On the flipside, General Mills (GIS) traded higher after reporting a EPS beat and revenues in line. Its Pet Food sales rose 16% beating estimates for a 15% rise at its Blue Buffalo unit. Cintas (CTAS) were higher after top and bottom line beats, whilst also raising its FY20 EPS forecast.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Tesla (TSLA) printed all-time highs rising 4% after reports it is to cut the price of its Model 3 Sedan in China by 20% or more. Dish (DISH) traded higher today after its co-founder and Chairman Ergen announced he has three letters from three banks prepared to offer USD 10bln to fund its new wireless network. Macerich (MAC) benefitted from an upgrade to neutral from underweight at JP Morgan. Macy’s (M) higher after a note from Cleveland research turning positive on the company after being a bear for 1.5 years, citing Q4 to date tracking has improved from Q3, adding comps appear inline and promotions less aggressive. Nvidia (NVDA) partnered with Tencent (700 HK) to launch a cloud gaming service in China.

*M&A: Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) and Peugeot (UG FP) agreed to a 50/50 merger which would value the combined company at USD 50bln, making it the 4th largest automaker in terms of volume, and 3rd largest in terms of revenue. However, all is not clear yet as the two still face regulatory hurdles from both the US and EU. Broadcom (AVGO) Is reportedly looking to sell its RF wireless chip unit, which is reportedly valued at USD 10bln. 9to5 Mac reported an opinion piece that Apple (AAPL) could be a potential suitor as it is already researching its own RF technology, making the tech behemoth a likely suitor. Cigna (CI) sold one of its units which sells non-medical insurance products to employers to New York Life Insurance Co, for USD 6.3bln, whilst also announcing a USD 4bln share repurchase programme. Illumina (ILMN) had its USD 1.2bln deal to acquire Pacific Biosciences of California (PACB) challenged by the FTC, who allege ILMN is aiming to unlawfully maintain a monopoly in the US market for next-gen. DNA sequencing systems by eliminating PACB as a threat. Elsewhere, sources reported that EU antitrust regulators are to unconditionally approve Nvidia’s (NVDA) USD 6.8bln acquisition of Mellanox Technologies (MLNX). The EU antitrust also reportedly cleared conditions of Danaher’s (DHR) USD 21.4bln bid for General Electric (GE) bio-pharma business, where DHR will sell five business to address competitive concerns.

* RIKSBANK PREVIEW: Riksbank Rate Decision due Thursday 19th December 08:30GMT / 09:30CET / 03:30EST. Consensus almost unanimously calls for a 25bp hike to 0.0%. Focus will be on confirming whether this is a “one-and-done” hike and the extent of dovish opposition. Click here for the full preview.

* NORGES PREVIEW: Norges Bank Rate Decision due Thursday 19th December 09:00GMT / 1000CET / 04:00EST. Rates expected unchanged at 1.50%; focus will be on any tweaks to September’s rate path. Norges Bank Regional Network Survey displayed a negative outlook for the economy ahead. Recent rhetoric has been minimal, and largely reiterations of the rate most likely remaining unchanged for the period ahead. Click here for the full preview.

* BANXICO is Thursday 19th December 19:00 GMT / 14:00 EST. The Mexican central bank is expected to cut rates by 25bp to 7.25%, which would be the fourth consecutive rate cut; all sixteen analysts surveyed by Reuters look for a cut. At its last confab, the Banxico opted to lower rates by 25bps; however, two board members, Heath and Esquivel opted for a deeper 50bp cut. The latest minutes revealed that the majority of members said the growth outlook had continued to deteriorate, noting that it was facing risks to inflation, and that monetary policy would be adjusted in a firm and opportune manner. Banxico tends to follow a similar footing to the US Federal Reserve, although now the Fed is on hold; Banxico previously has stated that although it monitors the Fed, it is not a direct determinant for its monetary policy decisions. Click here for full primer.

* FX WRAP: USD traded firmer again continuing its march over the 97-handle, although finding resistance just shy of the 97.50 level at 97.47. Fed Speak did little to alter the direction, given the comments were all very much in line with the broader Fed view. DXY resides around its 50 WMA 97.36 heading into Asia-Pac trade. GBP continued its demise with Cable breaking 1.31 to the downside with 1.3050 the next level of support ahead of tomorrow’s BoE rate decision where the MPC is expected to vote 7-2 in favour of standing pat on rates at 0.75%; today’s inflation data didn’t turn the dial, either. EUR traded lower against the buck despite a strong Ifo report, however participants will be eyeing rather large option expiries in the coming days with 2.6bln worth at 1.1150 on EURUSD, plus another 1.1bln at 1.1140-45. CAD traded firmer, finding slight strength after its inflation data was very much in line with expectations, although the BoC eyed average of Median/Trim/Common CPI ticked up ever so slightly to 2.17% from 2.07%. Antipodes traded flat against the buck, amid no real catalyst as participants await tier 1 data; Aussie jobs and NZ GDP. Havens also traded flat amid no further catalyst for price action as markets quieten down heading into the holiday period, however participants will particularly be eying option expiries in USDJPY on Friday where 2.7bln expires at 109.50 strike as well as tonight’s BoJ monetary policy meeting. XAU and CHF both were little changed, although XAU saw slight selling pressure during the session with no fundamental reasoning with desks citing a technical breakout, at the time XAU fell through the 50dma at 1477. In EMFX, TRY underperformed once again as the US senate passed a defence bill calling for Turkey sanctions over the S-400 defence system. ZAR initially traded weaker on reports the US is to review the trading status of South Africa, however the Rand pared losses and ended the day firmer against the buck amid Eskom treading through another day without further loadshedding. Also of note, Fitch affirmed South Africa at “BB+”, outlook “Negative”. MXN trades weaker likely on broad dollar weakness ahead of the latest Banxico rate decision tomorrow.

* UK INFLATION (NOV): CPI printed +0.2% M/M, in line with expectations; the Y/Y rate was unchanged at 1.5% against expectations of a fall to 1.4%. The core metric was unchanged at 1.7% Y/Y, in line with the previous and the consensus. Capital Economics said the data probably means the BOE will be content to sit on its hands at tomorrow's MPC meeting; but unless the tone of the economic news improves, there's still a chance that interest rates will be cut early next year, the consultancy wrote.

* PBOC: China's central bank cut the 14-day reverse repo rate by 5bps, to 2.65%, bolstering the case of those who think it will also cut its 1-year LPR rate on Friday by the same magnitude (to 4.10%). The central bank also injected USD 29bln of liquidity.

* SNB: Chair Jordan said he is "not excluding even more negative rates", explaining that without negative rates the CHF would see upside, endangering the Swiss economy. The interview follows remarks made last week, where Jordan stated rates would only be lowered further if "absolutely necessary," which some had taken as hawkish. One Swiss bank said it was watching FX and expected the SNB to cut rates if EURCHF fell to 1.06-1.07 before the SNB's March policy decision.

* JAPAN EXPORTS (NOV): Japanese exports have fallen for 12 straight months now, with data overnight showing exports now running at a clip of -7.9% Y/Y in November. The data was driven by soft shipments of autos and parts to the US, as well as weaker sales of chemical products to China.

subject: Micron Technology Inc (MU) Q1 20 (USD): Adj. EPS 0.48 (exp. 0.48), Revenue 5.14bln (exp. 5.03bln). Q2 EPS view 0.29-0.41 (exp. 0.41), Q2 Revenue view 4.5bln-4.8bln (exp. 4.82bln). Co sees Q2 as a bottoming out of its financial performance

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Dollar dominates, Lira loses and Antipodeans await tier 1 data
content:
DXY

Overall a solid session for the broad Dollar and Index as they continued to consolidate from heavy losses seen last week. Today saw a lack of fresh fundamentals to add to the overall narrative, albeit it’s worth noting that action across markets could be exaggerated in the run-up to Christmas amid holiday-thinned conditions and potential profit-taking/short-covering. US-China news-flow has been light, data has been scarce and speakers quiet. DXY is poised to end the EU session closer to the top of today’s 97.22-48 parameter having surpassed its 50 WMA at 97.36 with the psychological 97.50 mark the next resistance point to monitor. On a more domestic political front – the US House is to vote on the two articles of impeachment regarding the abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. Votes are expected to take place between 18:30 and 19:30 local time and President Trump will be impeached if either of the articles are adopted via a simple majority. If so, the trial then begins in the Republican-led Senate, which would require a two-thirds majority to remove Trump from office – seen as highly unlikely.

 

EUR, GBP

Sterling and Euro look to end the EU day modestly in the red, nonetheless today’s G10 underperformers. GBP/USD has given up the 1.3100 handle amid headwinds from the firmer Buck coupled with lingering jitters about a cliff-edge Brexit, after largely side-lining UK inflation data heading into tomorrow’s BoE Monetary Policy decision (full preview available on the Newsquawk Research Suite). The pair is poised to end EU trade closer to the bottom of its 1.3060-3134 daily band ahead of mild support at the psychological 1.3050, which also coincides with the 12th Dec low. Meanwhile, downside in the Single Currency had been somewhat cushioned by the EUR/GBP cross which reclaimed 0.85+ status. EUR/USD remains in the red – having clocked an intra-day range of 1.1110-54 and after failing to gain sustained support from overall upbeat German Ifo Survey and mostly unrevised EZ CPI. N.B: JPM notes of an estimated EUR 15-20bln of options structures running off between Thursday and Friday across EUR/USD, EUR/GBP and GBP/USD

 

AUD, NZD, CAD, JPY

All flat/modestly positive vs. the USD with the Loonie the standout outperformer among G10s as European markets head into the close. USD/CAD saw losses in light of mostly in-line Canadian inflation figures - but the kicker being a rise in the Median/Trim/Common average (2.17% vs. Prev. 2.07%). The pair looks to end the EU session at the bottom of todays 1.3116-76 parameter ahead of mild support at 1.3114 (16 Dec/05 Nov/25 Jul lows) having breached its 100 WMA (1.3132) to the downside. Meanwhile, the AUD, NZD and JPY are awaiting their respective tier 1 releases in the form of Aussie jobs data, NZ GDP and the BoJ Monetary Policy meeting (full preview available on the Newsquawk Research Suite) – AUD/USD remains within a tight band around 0.6850 (0.6839-59 daily range), NZD/USD resides just above 0.6550 (0.6554-80 intraday parameter), and USD/JPY ~109.50 having clocked in a daily range of 109.40-109.63 thus far. 

 

EM

The Turkish Lira has remained the EM underperformer after US senate passed a defence bill calling for Turkey sanctions over its purchase of the S-400 defence system – a bill which now falls into the hands of US President Trump for signing. The Turkish Defence Ministry responded that the bill contained hostile elements towards Turkey, in a sign that the relationship between the two countries are further deteriorating. USD/TRY has gained 5.900+ status to a high of 5.9200 (vs. low of 5.8829). Meanwhile, the ZAR experienced some weakness in early EU trade following source reports that the US is to review South Africa’s trade status at the end of January next year. USD/ZAR pared back earlier upside and reversed course to session lows (14.2818-4581 range), potentially on stabilisation on the Eskom front – which expects no load shedding today despite constrained systems, although the Rand may have received solace in anticipation of Fitch’s rating, which was affirmed.

subject: ANALYSIS: TRUMP IMPEACHMENT
content:
*TODAY’S VOTE

The US Democrat-controlled House will today vote on the two articles to of impeached announced by House Speaker Pelosi last week: 1) abuse of power and 2) obstruction of Congress. 

Votes are expected to begin around 18:30-19:30 local time (23:30-00:30 GMT) following approximately six hours of debate.

The House requires a simple majority (51%) to adopt the articles. If either article is adopted, then President Trump will be impeached.

*WHAT THEN?

If Trump is impeached, then the President will be tried in the Republican-controlled Senate. The Senate would require a two-thirds majority (67%) to convict the President and remove him from office – a scenario seen as almost impossible, judging from remarks of Republican Senators.

Accordingly, while the impeachment proceedings will generate a lot of column inches, it is likely that the market impact will be minimal for now, analysts believe.

Nomura quant desk says sentiment is just short of 'euphoric'; hedge funds are all buying stocks
content:
• Global stocks are holding near record highs, and although there has been some profit-taking into year-end, investors who had been holding back are being compelled to get into the market now after news of US/China 'phase one', Nomura says.
  • Nomura says sentiment has continued to improve, noting that its own gauge has moved from 'optimism' to 'euphoric'.
  • "Once sentiment crosses the line into euphoria, what often unfolds is an 'aerial dogfight' featuring the careless use of leverage and a wave of unusually rapidly executed direction trades," Nomura writes, "the result is the destabilization of the market trend." It adds that the standard move in these circumstances is to take profits and/or brace for downside.
  • Any downside may be limited, given the better macro news of late, Nomura says. However, it says that the present year-end rally is steeper than the historical norm, and it sees a scenario in which global equities peak sometime over the holidays, and then let off pressure in self-sustaining fashion for a time, possibly even through 20th January or so. "Although we expect a drawdown of 3% or more over this span, this period could turn out to be a welcome dip-buying opportunity, provided that the aforementioned good news remains true."
  • Nomura thinks that hedge funds' recent equity buying has an element of wishful thinking, and says that although the global economy is just showing the first signs of having begun to pick up, hedge funds have built up positions that appear premised on the idea that a V-shaped recovery in the global economy is already in the offing. "When this overdone optimism comes in for a reality check at the start of the new year, it seems unlikely that a middling pace of economic recovery will live up to speculators' expectations."
  • Looking at hedge fund strategies, Nomura suggests funds with a top-down view have been the strongest proponents of a bullish scenario. "We think something looks off-kilter in the way the market tone is quickly swinging to the supposition that the first-stage US-China trade agreement will bring about a seamless run of improvement in economic growth and corporate earnings, as if to justify the positions that hedge funds already hold."
  • The bank explains that global macro hedge funds' net long exposure to DM equities has in fact pulled far away to the upside from the Citi Major Economies Economic Surprise Index. "The same economic surprise index, meanwhile, has a clear seasonal tendency to improve through the end of the year (led by such factors as the holiday shopping season in the US) only to deteriorate with the start of the new year," and "given how high macro-oriented investors have set their sights, we think investors will need to pay close attention to whether the Citi Major Economies Economic Surprise Index comes up short of the market's overly high expectations in 2020."
  • Meanwhile, for CTAs and risk-parity funds, Nomura says algo traders are not buying stocks to the extent that macro funds are. It says CTAs are adding to their net long position in S&P 500 futures. "For as long as the S&P 500 holds above 3,110 (which we estimate to be the average entry point for CTAs' net buying since the end of October), CTAs look likely to keep up their trend-chasing buying," Nomura writes.
  • At the same time, end investors in the US have been increasing their buying of stocks through ETFs. "Of course, these investors are not algorithmic players, and their investment horizons differ from those of CTAs," nomura says, but it notes that ETF investments are essentially a trend-chasing strategy of sorts, and trend-following flows have been robust in both the futures market and the ETF market.
  • At the same time, Nomura says CTAs have also been selling bond futures, holding a small net long position in UST futures (TY), and the bank will be watching to see whether they tentatively exit their remaining longs at 10yr UST yields of 1.90% or higher. "However, CTAs have already closed out more than 90% of the net long position in DM government bond futures (UST futures, JGB futures, Euro-Bund futures, and Gilt futures) that they held as of the end-of-August peak," and "unless CTAs swing to going short, the systematic and unilateral bond-selling therefore looks likely to peter out."
  • Finally, Nomura notes that the positioning of risk-parity funds has seen a building up long positions in DM equities, but their exposure does not look overheated in the way it did in early 2018. "Their selling of investment-grade bonds since the summer has also come to a halt, so we expect there to now be less systematic bond-selling pressure associated with risk-parity funds' portfolio rebalancing."

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 18th December 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European Equities have been choppy for much of the session, but haven’t drifted too far from the unchanged mark
  • US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said President Trump just wants a level playing field with China and the enforcement mechanism is very strong in the China deal
  • US House had enough votes to impeach President Trump with the majority in favour and is expected to conduct a vote today
  • FX space is little changed vs. USD, with EUR and GBP failing to derive much support from the sessions data
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Canadian CPI, DoEs, NZ GDP, Trade Balance, Fed’s Evans

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed as the region lacked conviction in the absence of any fresh catalysts and following a relatively quiet session on Wall Street heading into the holiday season, where stocks consolidated around record highs due to the improved trade climate and after several encouraging tier-2 data releases. ASX 200 (+0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) were mixed as defensives just about offset the losses in miners, tech and financials to keep Australia afloat, while sentiment in Tokyo was weighed by adverse currency flows and mixed trade data in which Exports contracted for a 12th consecutive month albeit at a slightly narrower than expected decline. Hang Sang (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) were indecisive amid diminishing effects from the US-China phase one agreement, while the PBoC’s first liquidity injection in 21 sessions also failed to spur prices despite announcing a total of CNY 200bln via 7-day and 14-day reverse repos at a reduced rate (2.65% vs Prev. 2.70%) on the 14-day operation. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher following the bull-steepening in the US and with the BoJ also in the market for over JPY 1.1tln of JGBs in 1yr-10yr maturities, but with advances restricted as the BoJ kick starts its 2-day policy meeting.  

PBoC injected CNY 50bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 150bln via 14-day reverse repos with the 7-day reverse repo rate kept at 2.50% and 14-day reverse repo rate lowered to 2.65% from 2.70%. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY reference rate at 6.9969 vs. Exp. 6.9975 (Prev. 6.9971)

CNBC's Yoon suggested the PBoC 14-day reverse repo rate cut is a sign it remains in easing mode and may be just enough to convince banks to make another 5bps cut this Friday to the Loan Prime Rate citing Capital Economics. (Twitter)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said President Trump just wants a level playing field with China and the enforcement mechanism is very strong in the China deal. (Newswires)

Japanese Trade Balance (JPY)(Nov) -82.1B vs. Exp. -369.0B (Prev. 17.3B, Rev. 15.7B). (Newswires) Japanese Exports (Nov) Y/Y -7.9% vs. Exp. -8.6% (Prev. -9.2%) Japanese Imports (Nov) Y/Y -15.7% vs. Exp. -12.7% (Prev. -14.8%)

US

US House had enough votes to impeach President Trump with the majority in favour and is expected to conduct a vote today and the House Rules Committee set a rule for 6-hour debate ahead of the Trump impeachment vote. (Newswires)

UK/EU

The Times Shadow MPC saw a 7-2 vote in favour of standing pat on rates at 0.75% with the two dissenters voting for a rate increase (vs. two dovish dissenters on the actual MPC). The Panel said the BoE should abandon its bias towards lower rates next year. (Times)

UK Government’s plan is to get the Brexit Withdrawal Agreement Bill through House of Commons stages on the 7th, 8th and 9th of January., scheduling understanding via Spectators Forsyth. (Twitter)

French President Macron will not be abandoning pension reform plans, but is prepared for improvements during discussions with unions. (Newswires)

Poland’s Supreme Court warned the country may be forced to leave the EU if controversial reforms advocated by the ruling party is pushed through which would permit the dismissal of judges if they questioned the government's judicial reforms. (BBC)

 

Outgoing ECB Board Member Coeure says lowering the inflation target would be wrong, as an alternative, ECB could communicate the range of inflation outcomes that can be considered acceptable in normal times. (Newswires)

UK CPI YY (Nov) 1.5% vs. Exp. 1.4% (Prev. 1.5%)

-        Core CPI YY (Nov) 1.7% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.7%)

-        CPI MM (Nov) 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. -0.2%)

-        Core CPI MM (Nov) 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.1%)

German Ifo Business Climate New (Dec) 96.3 vs. Exp. 95.5 (Prev. 95.0, Rev. 95.1)

-        Expectations New (Dec) 93.8 vs. Exp. 93 (Prev. 92.1, Rev. 92.3)

-        Current Conditions New (Dec) 98.8 vs. Exp. 98.1 (Prev. 97.9, Rev. 98.0)

-        German economy is heading into the new year with confidence, Ifo says; adding that the industrial sector is still in recession and it will take a while to get out of it. And German GDP is likely to increase by 0.2% in Q4.

EQUITIES

FedEx Corp (FDX) reported Q4 19 Adj EPS USD 2.51 vs. Exp. 2.84, Revenue USD 17.3bln vs. Exp. USD 17.69bln. Co. cut its FY 20 EPS to USD 9.10-10.35 vs. Prev. USD 10.00-12.00. Co. said quarterly results declined due to weak global economic conditions, higher ground costs, loss of business from a large customer. (Newswires) Co. shares declined almost 7% in after-market trade.

A choppy day thus far for European stocks [Eurstoxx 50 +0.2%] following on from a mixed APAC session as markets quietened ahead of the Christmas holidays. Sectors are broadly mixed with some underperformance seen in consumer discretionary whilst staples outperform. The session has been mostly driven by individual stock movers – Fiat Chrysler (-0.1%) and Peugeot (+1.2%) have officially announced an agreement for a 50/50 merger in a EUR 50bln deal – with annual run-rate synergies expected at around USD 3.7bln.  Before the deal is closed, Fiat Chrysler stated it will distribute a special dividend of EUR 5.5bln while PSA will distribute to its shareholders its 46% stake in Faurecia (-1.5%). Further, Fiat Chrysler notes that its robot-making unit Comau is to be spun off after the merger. Elsewhere, FTSE-listed NMC Health (-0.5%) opened higher to the tune of 10% (following yesterday’s 20% drop) after the Co. reaffirmed its guidance and announced a GBP 200mln share buyback programme in response to Muddy Water’s negative note. Meanwhile, postal names including Deutsche Post (-0.7%), Royal Mail (-2.8%) and Austrian Post (-0.7%) all experience headwinds from FedEx’s (-7.4% pre-market) earnings last night which saw the company downgrade its EPS forecast alongside dismal earnings, citing weak global economic conditions. Elsewhere, Volvo (+4.1%) shares are supported after the Co. and Isuzu Motors (7202 JT) are mulling a strategic alliance. Volvo sees a positive impact on operating profit of SEK 2bln from the alliance. Finally, further angst for Scandi banks after the Swedish FSA opened as opened a sanctions case against the Co. and a probe into SEB’s (-1.6%) governance and control of measures to combat money laundering. FSA plans to communicate the outcome of the case in April 2020.

FX

DXY, CNH - The broad Dollar and Index remains in positive territory thus far in a continuation of the upside seen overnight, with the DXY meandering just under current weekly highs and its 50 WMA, both near 97.360 – somewhat of a barrier in recent trade. News-flow on the US-Sino front has been quiet overnight, with US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin singing from the same hymn sheet as recent WH officials. Nonetheless, the lack of details regarding the Phase One deal has prompted caution among traders and investors. This tone is reflected in CNY and CNH, with the offshore choppy on either side of 7.000 vs. the USD and with a lack of conviction and awaiting further headlines. Meanwhile, today’s docket sees little by way of State-side data, although speakers include Fed’s Board of Governor member Brainard and 2020 non-voter Evans.

EUR, GBP - Both trading modestly softer vs. the Buck and flat against each other. Sterling has held onto a bulk of yesterday’s losses and dipped below 1.3100 overnight before finding a base at around 1.3070 – with little reaction seen in light of mixed UK inflation metrics, in which headline CPI modestly topped forecasts alongside RPI, albeit PPI printed sub-par ahead of the BoE’s monetary policy update tomorrow. Elsewhere, EUR/USD saw very mild solace upon the German Ifo’s rosy release with all three metrics beating forecasts and priors seeing revisions higher. The institute added that the German Q4 German GDP is likely to increase by 0.2%. Aside from that, the Single Currency was little swayed by mostly unrevised EZ CPI figures with EUR/USD choppy within a tight 1.1127-54 intraday band (having retreated further below its 200 DMA at 1.1152). That said, decent option expiries may prompt some action amid holiday-thinned trade – with EUR 1.3bln expiring between strikes 1.1125-35 and a further EUR 1.6bln between 1.1140-50.

AUD, NZD, CAD, JPY - All flat and within tight ranges vs. the USD in early EU trade, albeit more on the back of a firmer Buck as opposed to individual weakness – with the high beta on standby for their respective tier one data/events (aside from trade news-flow). AUD/USD hovers around 0.6850 at time of writing ahead of the much-anticipated Aussie jobs data due overnight as an indication of the RBA’s next policy move. Similarly, its Kiwi counterpart remains relatively sideways and just north of 0.6550 and ahead of its 50 WMA (0.6585) with NZ Q3 GDP on the radar. USD/CAD remains just above the 1.3150 mark and with little inspiration from softer energy prices as the Loonie looks ahead to its November CPI readings – with headline YY seen ticking higher in the month. Analysts at JPM believe that the USD/CAD risk-reward remains skewered towards to the topside as the bank sees the BoC reducing rates at least once next year – “CPI sticking around target shouldn’t challenge that, but if it were to come off, then it would be another excuse to cut”, JPM says. Finally, USD/JPY trades lacklustre just under the 109.50 mark ahead of the BoJ Monetary Policy Decision due to be released sometime during the Tokyo lunch break (Full preview available on the Newsquawk headline feed).

EM - The Turkish Lira has seen renewed weakness after US senate passed a defence bill calling for Turkey sanctions over its purchase of the S-400 defence system – a bill which now falls into the hands of US President Trump for signing. The Turkish Defence Ministry responded that the bill contained hostile elements towards Turkey, in a sign that the relationship between the two countries are further deteriorating. USD/TRY has gained 5.900+ status to a high of 5.9200 (vs. low of 5.8829). Meanwhile, the ZAR experienced some weakness in early EU trade following source reports that the US is to review South Africa’s trade status at the end of January next year. USD/ZAR has pared back earlier upside, potentially on stabilisation on the Eskom front – which expects no loadshedding today despite constrained systems.

US is to review South Africa's preferential trade status on January 30th., according to sources. (Newswires)

Eskom states no load-shedding is expected today, due to a drop in demand and the return of some generating units. (Newswires)

Notable FX Expiries, NY Cut:

-        EUR/USD: 1.1045-50 (1.2BLN), 1.1075-85 (1.6BLN), 1.1100-10 (900M), 1.1125-35 (1.3BLN), 1.1140-50 (1.6BLN), 1.1185 (600M), 1.1200 (1.7BLN)

-        USD/CAD: 1.3210 (1.5BLN), 1.3340-50 (1.7BLN)

FIXED INCOME

Debt hasn’t drifted too far from the unchanged mark for the session thus far which has been relatively quiet ahead of the year’s final Super Thursday. Ahead of tomorrow’s BoE meeting, CPI came in at 1.5% YY, in-line with the prev. and slight above market expectations; although the BoE themselves do see inflation coming under renewed pressure on the effect of energy price caps (which were a hinderance last month). On the release, Gilts came under some mild pressure dropping by around 10 ticks to a session low of 131.94, albeit the dip below 132.0 was short-lived. German’s 10yr bond was similarly dented on the Ifo release where all metrics beat expectations and Ifo noted the German economy is moving into 2020 with confidence. However, CapEco believe the survey indicates the economy, while no-longer on a significant downward path, is still weak and will stagnate in Q4 at best. In terms of reaction, Bunds dipped to a session low of 171.96 (yesterday’s low) just after the release; for reference, further support lies just below at 171.81. Within the periphery, Greek debt is supported on reports that the ECB may allow Greek banks to increase their holdings of domestic debt. Stateside, it’s a relatively quiet session aside from some Fed speak from Evans at a Q&A which will not include a text release. In terms of price action, the curve is bull flattening at present, but not by a significant margin.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent are around USD 0.50/bbl lower at present but remain above the USD 60/bbl and USD 65/bbl levels respectively. News-flow for the crude complex, and generally, has been light this morning with price action continuing to be dictated by the surprise API build of 4.7mln barrels (Exp. draw 1.2mln barrels); ahead of today’s EIA release where expectations are for a headline draw of 1.288mln barrels. Looking ahead, UBS note that a extended period of inventory builds often begins in Q1 due to the gap between winter demand and US driving season; which, while expected they believe may prompt some profit taking. Elsewhere, spot gold is firmer by just shy of USD 3/oz and resides near the top of the sessions range, but remains below yesterday’s high of USD 1480.35/bbl. Finally, copper prices remain within a narrow range for the session given a quiet APAC session and no further updates, as of yet, on the US-China front.

API Energy Inventories Crude +4.7mln vs. Exp. -1.3mln (Prev. +1.4mln). (Newswires)

EQUITIES

A choppy day thus far for European stocks [Eurstoxx 50 +0.2%] following on from a mixed APAC session as markets quietened ahead of the Christmas holidays. Sectors are broadly mixed with some underperformance seen in consumer discretionary whilst staples outperform. The session has been mostly driven by individual stock movers – Fiat Chrysler (-0.1%) and Peugeot (+1.2%) have officially announced an agreement for a 50/50 merger in a EUR 50bln deal – with annual run-rate synergies expected at around USD 3.7bln.  Before the deal is closed, Fiat Chrysler stated it will distribute a special dividend of EUR 5.5bln while PSA will distribute to its shareholders its 46% stake in Faurecia (-1.5%). Further, Fiat Chrysler notes that its robot-making unit Comau is to be spun off after the merger. Elsewhere, FTSE-listed NMC Health (-0.5%) opened higher to the tune of 10% (following yesterday’s 20% drop) after the Co. reaffirmed its guidance and announced a GBP 200mln share buyback programme in response to Muddy Water’s negative note. Meanwhile, postal names including Deutsche Post (-0.7%), Royal Mail (-2.8%) and Austrian Post (-0.7%) all experience headwinds from FedEx’s (-7.4% pre-market) earnings last night which saw the company downgrade its EPS forecast alongside dismal earnings, citing weak global economic conditions. Elsewhere, Volvo (+4.1%) shares are supported after the Co. and Isuzu Motors (7202 JT) are mulling a strategic alliance. Volvo sees a positive impact on operating profit of SEK 2bln from the alliance. Finally, further angst for Scandi banks after the Swedish FSA opened as opened a sanctions case against the Co. and a probe into SEB’s (-1.6%) governance and control of measures to combat money laundering. FSA plans to communicate the outcome of the case in April 2020.

FX

DXY, CNH - The broad Dollar and Index remains in positive territory thus far in a continuation of the upside seen overnight, with the DXY meandering just under current weekly highs and its 50 WMA, both near 97.360 – somewhat of a barrier in recent trade. News-flow on the US-Sino front has been quiet overnight, with US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin singing from the same hymn sheet as recent WH officials. Nonetheless, the lack of details regarding the Phase One deal has prompted caution among traders and investors. This tone is reflected in CNY and CNH, with the offshore choppy on either side of 7.000 vs. the USD and with a lack of conviction and awaiting further headlines. Meanwhile, today’s docket sees little by way of State-side data, although speakers include Fed’s Board of Governor member Brainard and 2020 non-voter Evans.

EUR, GBP - Both trading modestly softer vs. the Buck and flat against each other. Sterling has held onto a bulk of yesterday’s losses and dipped below 1.3100 overnight before finding a base at around 1.3070 – with little reaction seen in light of mixed UK inflation metrics, in which headline CPI modestly topped forecasts alongside RPI, albeit PPI printed sub-par ahead of the BoE’s monetary policy update tomorrow. Elsewhere, EUR/USD saw very mild solace upon the German Ifo’s rosy release with all three metrics beating forecasts and priors seeing revisions higher. The institute added that the German Q4 German GDP is likely to increase by 0.2%. Aside from that, the Single Currency was little swayed by mostly unrevised EZ CPI figures with EUR/USD choppy within a tight 1.1127-54 intraday band (having retreated further below its 200 DMA at 1.1152). That said, decent option expiries may prompt some action amid holiday-thinned trade – with EUR 1.3bln expiring between strikes 1.1125-35 and a further EUR 1.6bln between 1.1140-50.

AUD, NZD, CAD, JPY - All flat and within tight ranges vs. the USD in early EU trade, albeit more on the back of a firmer Buck as opposed to individual weakness – with the high beta on standby for their respective tier one data/events (aside from trade news-flow). AUD/USD hovers around 0.6850 at time of writing ahead of the much-anticipated Aussie jobs data due overnight as an indication of the RBA’s next policy move. Similarly, its Kiwi counterpart remains relatively sideways and just north of 0.6550 and ahead of its 50 WMA (0.6585) with NZ Q3 GDP on the radar. USD/CAD remains just above the 1.3150 mark and with little inspiration from softer energy prices as the Loonie looks ahead to its November CPI readings – with headline YY seen ticking higher in the month. Analysts at JPM believe that the USD/CAD risk-reward remains skewered towards to the topside as the bank sees the BoC reducing rates at least once next year – “CPI sticking around target shouldn’t challenge that, but if it were to come off, then it would be another excuse to cut”, JPM says. Finally, USD/JPY trades lacklustre just under the 109.50 mark ahead of the BoJ Monetary Policy Decision due to be released sometime during the Tokyo lunch break (Full preview available on the Newsquawk headline feed).

EM - The Turkish Lira has seen renewed weakness after US senate passed a defence bill calling for Turkey sanctions over its purchase of the S-400 defence system – a bill which now falls into the hands of US President Trump for signing. The Turkish Defence Ministry responded that the bill contained hostile elements towards Turkey, in a sign that the relationship between the two countries are further deteriorating. USD/TRY has gained 5.900+ status to a high of 5.9200 (vs. low of 5.8829). Meanwhile, the ZAR experienced some weakness in early EU trade following source reports that the US is to review South Africa’s trade status at the end of January next year. USD/ZAR has pared back earlier upside, potentially on stabilisation on the Eskom front – which expects no loadshedding today despite constrained systems.

FIXED INCOME

Debt hasn’t drifted too far from the unchanged mark for the session thus far which has been relatively quiet ahead of the year’s final Super Thursday. Ahead of tomorrow’s BoE meeting, CPI came in at 1.5% YY, in-line with the prev. and slight above market expectations; although the BoE themselves do see inflation coming under renewed pressure on the effect of energy price caps (which were a hinderance last month). On the release, Gilts came under some mild pressure dropping by around 10 ticks to a session low of 131.94, albeit the dip below 132.0 was short-lived. German’s 10yr bond was similarly dented on the Ifo release where all metrics beat expectations and Ifo noted the German economy is moving into 2020 with confidence. However, CapEco believe the survey indicates the economy, while no-longer on a significant downward path, is still weak and will stagnate in Q4 at best. In terms of reaction, Bunds dipped to a session low of 171.96 (yesterday’s low) just after the release; for reference, further support lies just below at 171.81. Within the periphery, Greek debt is supported on reports that the ECB may allow Greek banks to increase their holdings of domestic debt. Stateside, it’s a relatively quiet session aside from some Fed speak from Evans at a Q&A which will not include a text release. In terms of price action, the curve is bull flattening at present, but not by a significant margin.

COMMODITIES 

WTI and Brent are around USD 0.50/bbl lower at present but remain above the USD 60/bbl and USD 65/bbl levels respectively. News-flow for the crude complex, and generally, has been light this morning with price action continuing to be dictated by the surprise API build of 4.7mln barrels (Exp. draw 1.2mln barrels); ahead of today’s EIA release where expectations are for a headline draw of 1.288mln barrels. Looking ahead, UBS note that a extended period of inventory builds often begins in Q1 due to the gap between winter demand and US driving season; which, while expected they believe may prompt some profit taking. Elsewhere, spot gold is firmer by just shy of USD 3/oz and resides near the top of the sessions range, but remains below yesterday’s high of USD 1480.35/bbl. Finally, copper prices remain within a narrow range for the session given a quiet APAC session and no further updates, as of yet, on the US-China front.

subject: European Equity Movers this Morning: Pearson (PSON LN) +4.1%; PSA Group (UG FP) +4.0%; Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM) +1.8%; SEB (SEBA SS) -5.5%; Faurecia (EO FP) -1.0%; Royal Mail (RMG LN) -2.0%; Casino (CO FP) -2.3%
Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news
content:
ABB (ABBN SW) – Co. has completed the divestment in Shanghai of two electrification JVs. (Newswires)

Aena (AENA SM) - CNMC (Spanish Competition Watchdog) has lowered the Co's airport fees for 2020 to -1.44% vs. Co's proposed -1.17%. (Newswires)

Airbus (AIR FP) – Co. is reportedly in talks with employee representatives in an attempt to improve cost structure, according to reports. Co. added that its defence and space units saw headwinds in the last three years. Separately, the Co. expects all civil aircraft programmes to exceed book-to-bill ratio of 1, according to its Sales Chief; adding that the development of a larger version of the A220 is not on the agenda at present. Co’s CCO says the book to bill ratio is ‘very satisfactory’ across all programmes in 2019, and they are not profiting from the Boeing (BA) crisis. (Newswires)

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – Co’s Lynparza has been recommended by FDA advisory committee for 1st-line maintenance treatment of metastatic pancreatic cancer. (Newswires)

Daimler (DAI GY)/ BMW (BMW GY) – Cos, alongside Apple (AAPL) and Cisco (CISCO), have urged European Commission to take actions on patent abuses that hamper the development of self-driving vehicles and connected devices. (FT)

Daimler (DAI GY) – Co’s JV partner BAIC (1958 HK) shares fell 5.3% in Hong Kong trade. (Newswires)

ITV (ITV LN) – Sky are reportedly developing plans for Sky News Local, and as such have been lobbying Ofcom (UK Media Watchdog) to open the local news services to new competition. For reference, the current system guarantees ITV and BBC prominence in channel menus, partially, in exchange for the amount they spend on news output for localised areas. (Telegraph)

NMC Health (NMC LN) – Co’s chairman, in response to the Muddy Waters report, stated that the group holds itself to the highest standards across its entire portfolio. Further, Co. affirmed its broader trading and operational guidance for 2019 and 2020. Co. stated it will begin a USD 200mln share buyback programme. Co. stated that it will respond to the Muddy Waters report in due course. (Newswires) This comes after Co. shares fell 20% after activist short-seller Muddy Waters noted of serious doubt about the Co's financial statement, its asset values, cash balance, reported profits, and reported debt levels.

Pearson (PSON LN) – Co. are to sell their remaining 25% stake in Penguin Random House to Bertelsmann for circa USD 675mln; additionally, Co. announce a GBP 375mln share buyback. (Newswires)

Persimmon (PSN LN) – A review by a law firm has resulted in the Co. being told to overhaul its culture, improve its homes and reconsider their executive bonuses. (FT)

Rio Tinto (RIO LN) – Co. has reportedly closed a deal with Tasmania for lower power costs for Bell Bay. (AFR)

DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

18th December 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed as the region lacked conviction in the absence of any fresh catalysts and following a relatively quiet session on Wall Street heading into the holiday season, where stocks consolidated around record highs due to the improved trade climate and after several encouraging tier-2 data releases. ASX 200 (+0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) were mixed as defensives just about offset the losses in miners, tech and financials to keep Australia afloat, while sentiment in Tokyo was weighed by adverse currency flows and mixed trade data in which Exports contracted for a 12th consecutive month albeit at a slightly narrower than expected decline. Elsewhere, Hang Sang (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were indecisive amid diminishing effects from the US-China phase one agreement, while the PBoC’s first liquidity injection in 21 sessions also failed to spur prices despite announcing a total of CNY 200bln via 7-day and 14-day reverse repos at a reduced rate (2.65% vs Prev. 2.70%) on the 14-day operation.

FTSE 100

British American Tobacco (BATS LN) – Co. has been ordered by the Advertising Standards Authority to stop promoting e-cigarettes on social media after the watchdog found that the Co’s posts “clearly went beyond” allowed marketing of vaping production. (FT)

Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA LN) – Co. has revealed that it did not pay corporate income tax in the UK in 2018, reporting USD 731mln of pre-tax profit on revenues of USD 108bln. Co. also admitted that it did not pay corporate income tax in Netherlands last year, apart from its JV with ExxonMobil (XOM). (Telegraph)

NMC Health (NMC LN) – Co’s chairman, in response to the Muddy Waters report, stated that the group holds itself to the highest standards across its entire portfolio. (Newswires) This comes after Co. shares fell 20% after activist short-seller Muddy Waters noted of serious doubt about the Co's financial statement, its asset values, cash balance, reported profits, and reported debt levels.

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

DAX

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Scout24 (G24 GY) - Co. confirms the sale of Autoscout24 to Hellman & Friedman for EUR 2.89bln. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Airbus (AIR FP) – Co. is reportedly in talks with employee representatives in an attempt to improve cost structure, according to reports. Co. added that its defence and space units saw headwinds in the last three years. (Newswires)

Credit Agricole (ACA FP) – Co. is to take a goodwill impairment charge of roughly EUR 600mln recognised against LCL. The co. adds there will be no impact on solvency ratios or the dividend. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

CASINO (CO FP) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM FROM HOLD AT JEFFERIES

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

Deutsche Post (DPW GY)/ Austrian Post (POST AV)/ Poste Italiane (PST IM)/ Royal Mail (RMG LN) - FedEx Corp (FDX) reported Q4 19 Adj EPS USD 2.51 vs. Exp. 2.84, Revenue USD 17.3bln vs. Exp. USD 17.69bln. Co. cut its FY 20 EPS to USD 9.10-10.35 vs. Prev. USD 10.00-12.00. Co. said quarterly results declined due to weak global economic conditions, higher ground costs, loss of business from a large customer. (Newswires) Co. shares declined almost 7% in after-market trade.

PSA (UG FP)/ Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM) – The two Co’s have agreed to a 50/50 merger in a EUR 50bln deal. The merger will deliver ~3.7bln estimated annual run-rate synergies with no plant closures resulting from the transaction. Synergies are expected to be net cash flow positive from year 1, completion of the deal should take place in 12-15 months. The merged entity will have a recurring operating profit of over EUR 11bln and profit margin on 6.6%. Before the deal is closed, Fiat Chrysler will distribute a special dividend of EUR 5.5bln while PSA will distribute to its shareholders its 46% stake in Faurecia (EO FP). Further, Fiat Chrysler notes that its robot-making unit Comau is to be spun off after the merger. Separately, Dongfeng will reduce its stake in PSA as part of the merger deal with Fiat Chrysler, according to sources. Dongfeng intends to hold around 4.5% of the combined PSA-FCA group vs. its current 12% holding in PSA. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SMI

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

Volvo (VOLVB SS) – Co. and Isuzu Motors (7202 JT) are mulling a strategic alliance. Volvo sees a positive impact on operating profit of SEK 2bln from the alliance. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

US

subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 18th December 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets traded mixed as the region lacked conviction in the absence of any fresh catalysts and following a relatively quiet session on Wall Street
  • US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said President Trump just wants a level playing field with China and the enforcement mechanism is very strong in the China deal
  • S&P affirmed UK at AA; Outlook revised to Stable from Negative and Fitch affirmed the UK at AA; Outlook revised to Negative from Rating Watch Negative
  • US House has enough votes to impeach President Trump with the majority in favour and is expected to conduct a vote today
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German IFO, UK & Canadian CPI, EZ CPI (Final), DoEs, NZ GDP, Trade Balance, ECB’s Lagarde, Coeure, Fed’s Brainard and Evans

1ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed as the region lacked conviction in the absence of any fresh catalysts and following a relatively quiet session on Wall Street heading into the holiday season, where stocks consolidated around record highs due to the improved trade climate and after several encouraging tier-2 data releases. ASX 200 (+0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) were mixed as defensives just about offset the losses in miners, tech and financials to keep Australia afloat, while sentiment in Tokyo was weighed by adverse currency flows and mixed trade data in which Exports contracted for a 12th consecutive month albeit at a slightly narrower than expected decline. Hang Sang (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were indecisive amid diminishing effects from the US-China phase one agreement, while the PBoC’s first liquidity injection in 21 sessions also failed to spur prices despite announcing a total of CNY 200bln via 7-day and 14-day reverse repos at a reduced rate (2.65% vs Prev. 2.70%) on the 14-day operation. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher following the bull-steepening in the US and with the BoJ also in the market for over JPY 1.1tln of JGBs in 1yr-10yr maturities, but with advances restricted as the BoJ kick starts its 2-day policy meeting.  

PBoC injected CNY 50bln via 7-day reverse repos and CNY 150bln via 14-day reverse repos with the 7-day reverse repo rate kept at 2.50% and 14-day reverse repo rate lowered to 2.65% from 2.70%. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY reference rate at 6.9969 vs. Exp. 6.9975 (Prev. 6.9971)

CNBC's Yoon suggested the PBoC 14-day reverse repo rate cut is a sign it remains in easing mode and may be just enough to convince banks to make another 5bps cut this Friday to the Loan Prime Rate citing Capital Economics. (Twitter)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said President Trump just wants a level playing field with China and the enforcement mechanism is very strong in the China deal. (Newswires)

Japanese Trade Balance (JPY)(Nov) -82.1B vs. Exp. -369.0B (Prev. 17.3B, Rev. 15.7B). (Newswires) Japanese Exports (Nov) Y/Y -7.9% vs. Exp. -8.6% (Prev. -9.2%) Japanese Imports (Nov) Y/Y -15.7% vs. Exp. -12.7% (Prev. -14.8%)

UK/EU

S&P affirmed UK at AA; Outlook revised to Stable from Negative and Fitch affirmed the UK at AA; Outlook revised to Negative from Rating Watch Negative. (Newswires)

The Times Shadow MPC saw a 7-2 vote in favour of standing pat on rates at 0.75% with the two dissenters voting for a rate increase (vs. two dovish dissenters on the actual MPC). The Panel said the BoE should abandon its bias towards lower rates next year. (Times)

Poland’s Supreme Court warned the country may be forced to leave the EU if controversial reforms advocated by the ruling party is pushed through which would permit the dismissal of judges if they questioned the government's judicial reforms. (BBC)

FX DXY remained slightly firmer and marginally extended above the 97.00 level after the recent flurry of better than expected data releases including Industrial Production and Housing Starts. In addition, the greenback also benefitted from recent weakness in its major counterparts in which EUR/USD retreated from its 200DMA of 1.1152 and GBP/USD continued its rout to briefly below 1.3100 after Brexit cliff fears were triggered yesterday. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were lower amid the lacklustre risk appetite in Japan and mixed trade data, while antipodeans were also uneventful due to their high beta statuses and as CNY weakened past the 7.0000 level against USD.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were lacklustre overnight in which WTI crude futures pulled back from the prior day’s gains as the advances were stalled by resistance at the USD 61.00/bbl level with the reversal exacerbated by a bearish API release which showed a surprise build in headline crude inventories, as well as much larger than expected builds in gasoline and distillate stockpiles. Elsewhere, gold prices remained flat with the precious metal constrained by the mild appreciation for the greenback, while copper was subdued and tested the USD 2.8/lb level as the US-China phase one trade euphoria dwindled.

 

API Energy Inventories Crude +4.7mln vs. Exp. -1.3mln (Prev. +1.4mln). (Newswires) US 

The Treasury curve saw slight bull-steepening on Tuesday, though the magnitude of the moves was not anything to write home about. The complex pared gains after decent data (housing starts/permits, as well as IP/manufacturing output), while desks also continue to cite the US/China phase one deal, while remarks from Fed's Kaplan (who votes in 2020) favoured rates being where they are. Some analysts also observed that Treasury vol in the longer dated part of the curve was the lowest in six months, as desks wind down for the year amid few major catalysts to trade ahead of year-end. T-note (H0) futures settled 1 tick higher at 128-14+.

Fed's Rosengren (non-voter in 2020, hawk) said additional policy easing is likely unnecessary in the near term and the economy is currently in a good place, which has performed as expected despite recent concerns about slower global growth and trade uncertainty. Rosengren added that an economic downturn is unlikely in 2020 given generally positive economic conditions and the continuation of accommodative monetary and fiscal policies, and assuming no significant negative shock, (Newswires)

US House had enough votes to impeach President Trump with the majority in favour and is expected to conduct a vote today and the House Rules Committee set a rule for 6-hour debate ahead of the Trump impeachment vote. (Newswires)

US Rep. Hoyer said the House will consider the USMCA trade pact on Thursday. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia lacks conviction in the absence of fresh catalysts and as 'phase one' tailwinds diminish
content:
Asia equity markets trade mixed with the region lacking conviction in the absence of any fresh catalysts and following a relatively quiet session on Wall Street heading into the holiday season, where stocks consolidated around record highs due to the improved trade climate and after several encouraging tier-2 data releases. ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) are mixed with defensives just about offsetting the losses in miners, tech and financials to keep Australia afloat, while sentiment in Tokyo is weighed by adverse currency flows and mixed trade data in which Exports contracted for a 12th consecutive month albeit at a slightly narrower than expected decline. Hang Sang (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) are positive but with gains limited by the diminishing effects from the US-China phase one agreement, while minimal upside was also seen despite the PBoC’s first liquidity injection in 21 sessions in which it injected a total of CNY 200bln via 7-day and 14-day reverse repos at a reduced rate (2.65% vs Prev. 2.70%) on the 14-day operation.

In FX markets, DXY remains slightly firmer and marginally extends above the 97.00 level after the recent flurry of better than expected data releases including Industrial Production and Housing Starts. The greenback also benefits from recent weakness in its major counterparts with EUR/USD retreating from its 200DMA of 1.1152 and with GBP/USD continuing its rout to below 1.3100 after Brexit cliff fears were triggered by government plans to rule out any extension to the transition period through an amended WAB. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses are lower amid the lacklustre risk appetite in Japan and mixed trade data, while antipodeans are also uneventful due to their high beta statuses and after a relatively stable CNY reference rate.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher following the bull-steepening in the US and with the BoJ also in the market for over JPY 1.1tln of JGBs in 1yr-10yr maturities, but with gains limited as the BoJ kicks start its 2-day policy meeting.

Huawei - US is considering new restrictions on sales to Huawei by US firms, while other reports noted that the US is finalising the initial batch of rules to limit exports of sophisticated technology to China and other countries and that US tech export rules seem to be more narrowly tailored than initially feared. (Newswires)

 

Trade

USTR Lighthizer said a Phase One trade deal is 'totally enforceable' and that there is plenty of leverage on both sides to ensure the agreement works, while he repeated his view that he expects US agriculture sales to China to double overnight. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said President Trump just wants a level playing field with China and that enforcement mechanism is very strong in the China deal. (Newswires)

US officials said that China Phase One is enough for now and Phase Two may come ‘sometime’ in 2020, while officials are happy to embrace the current deal and end the regular threat of tariff escalations and take whatever market and economic bounce they can get. (Politico)

 

Other News

Beijing reportedly has no plans to launch major fiscal stimulus to boost slowing growth, says top economic planning agency, while policymakers are increasingly upbeat about economic prospects after a rebound in industrial production last month and a phase one trade deal with the US. (Newswires)

PBoC Adviser Ma is said to urge China to prevent risks of local government financing vehicle failures and calls of a takeover of weak LGFVs. (Newswires)

 

Data Recap

  • China November YTD fiscal revenues rose 3.8% Y/Y and Expenditures rose 7.7% Y/Y. (Newswires)
  • Hong Kong Unemployment Rate (Oct) 3.2% vs. Exp. 3.2% (Prev. 3.1%). (Newswires)
